subject: Re:Re: Re:Re: Ask some questions about source code of JUnit
msgSnippet: Dear J. B. Rainsberger, ... I know it is an abstract class. But abstract class BaseTestRunner implements TestListener, not implements TestRunListener. please
messageBody:
Dear J. B. Rainsberger,

>> Thank you, I find it.
>> But I still don't understand how BaseTestRunner implement the interface
>> TestRunListener.
>> In class BaseTestRunner, there is an explanation "// TestRunListener
>> implementation" before "public abstract void testStarted(String
>> testName);" Then how can BaseTestRunner implement it? The signature of
>> BaseTestRunner is "public abstract class BaseTestRunner implements
>> TestListener", so it implements two interfaces, TestListener and
>> TestRunListener?
>
>In Java, an abstract class can implement an interface even if all the
>methods are abstract.
>
>BaseTestRunner is a base class itself. Its subclasses implement the
>TestRunListener methods. Declaring that BaseTestRunner implements
>TestRunListener, but declaring all the methods abstract removes duplication.

I know it is an abstract class.
But abstract class BaseTestRunner implements TestListener, not implements TestRunListener.
please note: TestListener, not TestRunListener.
I am fuzzed. :(


Regards!

F. Don 2004-04-15
dongsquare@...
